awd_titl_txt: PENN-UPR Partnership for Research and Education in Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
****Non-Technical Abstract****
The PENN-UPR PREM will further advance knowledge in materials science with new research efforts that will lead to the development of more efficient, cheaper and environmentally friendly electronic devices for health, environmental, domestic and industrial applications. A diverse group of faculty researchers from three undergraduate campuses of the University of Puerto Rico (UPR): Humacao, Cayey and Bayamon, and the University of Pennsylvania (PENN) Materials Research Science and Engineering Center will work in multidisciplinary teams with significant participation of HS and undergraduate students. The program will sustain a successful collaboration between UPR and PENN that began in 1998 with the NSF CIRE program and has continued with PREM support since 2004.  It will further increase the participation of minorities, women, and students from disadvantaged backgrounds (low income families, first generation in college, and from isolated rural areas) into materials research through a well-orchestrated education effort that starts with informal community science activities and with the participation of Middle and HS teachers, identifies and guides talented and motivated HS (and K-8) students through undergraduate schools focused on PREM research. This guided experience through a stimulating education, participation in competitive materials research, training in state-of-the-art research facilities and contact with role models, will promote high rates of students continuing graduate studies and joining the science and technology workforce.

****Technical Abstract****
The PENN-UPR PREM research and education efforts will be centered on two Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs): 1) Multi-functional nanodevices from optoelectronic materials, and 2) Nanoscale interactions of macromolecules at soft and hard interfaces. IRG 1 will synthesize, characterize, and manipulate optoelectronic materials to gain fundamental understanding of transport mechanisms in these materials for potential device applications. The projects include the study of new device structure combinations of single-atomic-layer materials (MoS2, etc.) and nanofibers of electro-active polymers that hold potential for transformative discoveries in chemical detection and energy harvesting.  IRG 2 will explore nanoscale interactions of macromolecules with soft and hard interfaces with the long-range goal of assembling nanomaterials into macroscopic structures with designed properties and functionality. The study of nanoparticle-protein interactions represents both a fundamental problem, as well as a research area for which the PENN-UPR team is uniquely poised to attack in terms of nanoparticle synthesis, protein chemistry, spectroscopy, and theory. The multidisciplinary research teams of UPR and PENN faculty will integrate undergraduates and HS students into extended research experiences that will lead to publishable results. Importantly, faculty will also integrate their research topics, techniques, and results into laboratory experiences, courses, and outreach activities. Finally, with support from an external Evaluator, the effectiveness of the program and the short and long-term impact on minority undergraduate institutions will be assessed.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The UPR-PENN PREM builds on long-term collaborative successes between the University of Puerto Rico (UPR) (Humacao, Cayey, and Bayam?n undergraduate campuses) and the University of Pennsylvania?s (PENN) MRSEC. The intellectual merit of the 2015-2022 PREM derives from the close integration of research and education, centered on two Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs): (1) Multifunctional nanodevices from optoelectronic materials and (2)Nanoscale interactions of macromolecules at soft and hard interfaces.   During the award period, multi-disciplinary and multi-institutional teams addressed important scientific questions with significant participation of undergraduates and high school students. 

  • Faculty and student researchers in IRG-1 synthesized, characterized, and manipulated optoelectronic materials to develop a fundamental understanding of charge transport mechanisms with an eye for potential device applications.They studied electronic transport mechanisms and novel properties of devices using 2D transition metal dichalcogenides, carbon-based materials (carbon spheres, graphene oxide and carbon nanotubes), conducting polymers, and ferroelectric polymers. They fabricated 2D/1D heterojunction diodes by crossing 2D materials with conducting polymer nanofibers.  Using ionic liquid gels (IL) as the gate dielectric, they fabricated diodes and field-effect transistors with superior performance and showed that field-effect transistors (FETs) with polymeric ferroelectrics as the gate dielectric can be implemented in read-out memory devices. They theoretically analyzed thermoelectric properties of quantum dots and single-molecule junctions both within and beyond the linear response regime and examined potential applications of double quantum dot systems as heat diodes. 
  • Faculty and student researchers in IRG-2 explored nanoscale interactions of macromolecules with soft and hard interfaces, with the goal of engineering interfacial properties for applications in bio separation, bioremediation, and electronics. They developed a new method to quantify the density and analyze the distribution of ligands on cellulose membranes, using fluorometry and Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy. They further used machine learning techniques to determine or predict the membrane ligand concentration. In addition, they demonstrated that gallium nitrite nanoparticle?s surface and total concentration are factors that modulate the aggregation kinetics of the amyloid peptides Aβ40 and IAPP. 

PREM has broadly impacted society by diversifying the pipeline of materials scientists with a well-orchestrated strategy that defines a pathway that starts with community informal science activities and then identifies talented and motivated HS and UG students for PREM research and guides them to graduate school.

  • During the grant cycle 2015-2022, 62 students who participated in research with PREM faculty (33 women) graduated with bachelor?s degrees from STEM disciplines at UPR-Humacao and UPR-Cayey. Of these, 42 (68%) continued graduate studies in the USA mainland and Puerto Rico.  Three (3) have graduated with PhDs, 2 with master?s degrees, and 37 continue enrolled in PhD programs (15 are PhD candidates). The PhD and MS graduates are working in industry. Of the 20 who did not go to graduate school immediately, 14 are working in industry, 2 in NASA, 2 as research assistants, and 2 are STEM teachers/educators.
  • One hundred and twenty-one (121) students graduated from high school (79 women), 100% continued college studies, 95 of them in STEM fields (78.5%). 
  • In 2015-2020, more than 15,000 Hispanic students, teachers, faculty, and public (over 50% women) participated in PREM education and outreach activities that included workshops, open houses, visits to schools and communities, and exhibits. Larger events for communities included, the Nano Exhibici?n presented at the Fort Museum in the island municipality of Vieques, Puerto Rico, and Explore Science: Zoom into Nano, presented at the Martorellrural community in Yabucoa, Puerto Rico. 
  • The PREM Spring Symposium, an annual scientific conference has created a forum for the materials science community in PR to discuss cutting-edge research topics and discuss new collaborations.

 


Last Modified: 10/15/2022
Modified by: Idalia Ramos
por.por_txt_cntn:
The UPR-PENN PREM builds on long-term collaborative successes between the University of Puerto Rico (UPR) (Humacao, Cayey, and Bayam?n undergraduate campuses) and the University of Pennsylvania?s (PENN) MRSEC. The intellectual merit of the 2015-2022 PREM derives from the close integration of research and education, centered on two Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs): (1) Multifunctional nanodevices from optoelectronic materials and (2)Nanoscale interactions of macromolecules at soft and hard interfaces.   During the award period, multi-disciplinary and multi-institutional teams addressed important scientific questions with significant participation of undergraduates and high school students. 

Faculty and student researchers in IRG-1 synthesized, characterized, and manipulated optoelectronic materials to develop a fundamental understanding of charge transport mechanisms with an eye for potential device applications.They studied electronic transport mechanisms and novel properties of devices using 2D transition metal dichalcogenides, carbon-based materials (carbon spheres, graphene oxide and carbon nanotubes), conducting polymers, and ferroelectric polymers. They fabricated 2D/1D heterojunction diodes by crossing 2D materials with conducting polymer nanofibers.  Using ionic liquid gels (IL) as the gate dielectric, they fabricated diodes and field-effect transistors with superior performance and showed that field-effect transistors (FETs) with polymeric ferroelectrics as the gate dielectric can be implemented in read-out memory devices. They theoretically analyzed thermoelectric properties of quantum dots and single-molecule junctions both within and beyond the linear response regime and examined potential applications of double quantum dot systems as heat diodes. 
Faculty and student researchers in IRG-2 explored nanoscale interactions of macromolecules with soft and hard interfaces, with the goal of engineering interfacial properties for applications in bio separation, bioremediation, and electronics. They developed a new method to quantify the density and analyze the distribution of ligands on cellulose membranes, using fluorometry and Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy. They further used machine learning techniques to determine or predict the membrane ligand concentration. In addition, they demonstrated that gallium nitrite nanoparticle?s surface and total concentration are factors that modulate the aggregation kinetics of the amyloid peptides Aβ40 and IAPP. 

PREM has broadly impacted society by diversifying the pipeline of materials scientists with a well-orchestrated strategy that defines a pathway that starts with community informal science activities and then identifies talented and motivated HS and UG students for PREM research and guides them to graduate school.

During the grant cycle 2015-2022, 62 students who participated in research with PREM faculty (33 women) graduated with bachelor?s degrees from STEM disciplines at UPR-Humacao and UPR-Cayey. Of these, 42 (68%) continued graduate studies in the USA mainland and Puerto Rico.  Three (3) have graduated with PhDs, 2 with master?s degrees, and 37 continue enrolled in PhD programs (15 are PhD candidates). The PhD and MS graduates are working in industry. Of the 20 who did not go to graduate school immediately, 14 are working in industry, 2 in NASA, 2 as research assistants, and 2 are STEM teachers/educators.
One hundred and twenty-one (121) students graduated from high school (79 women), 100% continued college studies, 95 of them in STEM fields (78.5%). 
In 2015-2020, more than 15,000 Hispanic students, teachers, faculty, and public (over 50% women) participated in PREM education and outreach activities that included workshops, open houses, visits to schools and communities, and exhibits. Larger events for communities included, the Nano Exhibici?n presented at the Fort Museum in the island municipality of Vieques, Puerto Rico, and Explore Science: Zoom into Nano, presented at the Martorellrural community in Yabucoa, Puerto Rico. 
The PREM Spring Symposium, an annual scientific conference has created a forum for the materials science community in PR to discuss cutting-edge research topics and discuss new collaborations.
